sen.j: 多芸荘（たきのしょう）は、平安時代または鎌倉時代～室町時代にかけて美濃国にあった荘園。
sen.e: Taki-no-sho Estate (多芸荘) was a shoen (manor in medieval Japan) existed in Mino Province in the Heian Period or during the Kamakura and Muromachi Period.
sen.cmt: 多芸荘→セル６に漢字表記の説明が出てくるので、名前の漢字を併記しました。Taki-no-sho Estate (多芸荘)
sen.e: Taki-no-sho Manor (多芸荘) was a shoen (manor in medieval Japan) existed in Mino Province in the Heian period or during the Kamakura and Muromachi periods.
Taki-no-sho Manor (多芸荘) was a shoen (manor in medieval Japan) existed in Mino Province in the Heian period or during the Kamakura and Muromachi periods.
It was an estate of Imperial Family.
It was an estate of Imperial Family.
It was an estate of Imperial Family.
It was also written as 多岐荘 and 多記荘.
It was also written as 多岐荘 and 多記荘.
It was also written as 多岐荘 and 多記荘.
Taki Country, Mino Province
Taki District, Mino Province
Taki District, Mino Province

sen.j: 現在の岐阜県養老町北部と大垣市の一部。
sen.e: It was extended from the northern part of present Yoro-cho, Gifu Prefecture to a part of present Ogaki City.
It consisted of an area covering modern-day Yoro-cho, Gifu Prefecture and part of Ogaki City.
It consisted of an area covering modern-day Yoro-cho, Gifu Prefecture and part of Ogaki City.
About 138.83ha as of the year 872.
About 138.83ha as of the year 872.
About 138.83ha as of the year 872.

sen.j: ただし、後世と同じ多芸荘かどうかは不明。
sen.e: Although it is uncertain whether this figure is that of the estate known as Taki-no-sho Estate in the later days.
Although it is uncertain whether this figure is that of the Taki-no-sho Manor of subsequent ages.
Although it is uncertain whether this figure is that of the Taki-no-sho Manor of subsequent ages.

Unknown
Unknown

sen.j: 貞観寺→鎌倉幕府（源頼朝→纐纈盛安（半領統治））→皇室（八条女院→後宇多天皇ら）
sen.e: Teikan-ji Temple → Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) (MINAMOTO no Yoritomo→ Moriyasu AYUSE（ruling a half of the territory）) → Imperial family (Hachijo Nyoin→ Emperor Gouda, etc）.
sen.cmt: 纐纈盛安→Moriyasu AYUSE (纐纈盛安) [正しい読み方が不明です] 半領統治→定訳不明： ruling a half of the territoryとしました。
sen.e: Teikan-ji Temple → Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) (MINAMOTO no Yoritomo → Moriyasu AYUSE （ruling half of the territory）) → Imperial family (Hachijo Nyoin → Emperor Gouda, etc.）.
sen.cmt: ・矢印の前のスペースを２つ補足・括弧の前のスペースを１つ補足・不必要な「a」を削除・ペリオドを補足
sen.e: Teikan-ji Temple → Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) (MINAMOTO no Yoritomo → Moriyasu AYUSE （ruling half of the territory）) → Imperial family (Hachijo Nyoin → Emperor Gouda, etc.）.

sen.j: 室町時代には土岐氏・明智氏・佐々木氏・島田氏らか地頭となって勢力を増し、15世紀末に斎藤氏が地頭になる頃には接収された。
sen.e: During the Muromachi Period, the such clans as Toki, Akechi, Sasaki and Shimada, enhanced the power as jito (land steward appointed by the central military government to each of the estates (shoen) into which the countryside was divided) and by the late 15th century, when the Saito clan became Jito, the manor was requisitioned.
sen.cmt: 地頭→jito (land steward appointed by the central military government to each of the estates (shoen) into which the countryside was divided) [http://encyclopedia2.thefeedictionary.com/jito]
sen.e: During the Muromachi Period, clans such as Toki, Akechi, Sasaki and Shimada enhanced their power as jito (manager and lord of a manor), and the manor was requisitioned at the end of the 15th century when the Saito clan became jito.
sen.cmt: ・不必要なコンマを２つ削除・「the such clans as」→「clans such as」・「the」→「their」・地頭を「jito (manager and lord of a manor)」にしました「late」→「end of the」・「Jito」→「jito」・文の後半を再構成
sen.e: During the Muromachi Period, clans such as Toki, Akechi, Sasaki and Shimada enhanced their power as jito (manager and lord of a manor), and the manor was requisitioned at the end of the 15th century when the Saito clan became jito.
